Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2017 International Particle Accelerator Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for US students to participate in the primary annual international conference on accelerator science and its applications, the 8th International Particle Accelerator Conference (IPAC`17) to be held in Copenhagen, Denmark on May 14-19, 2017. The IPACs are an annual series of conferences that rotate between the Americas, Europe, and Asia to highlight the science and engineering of major accelerator facilities, provide scientists with a forum for presenting results from research conducted using accelerators, and serve as a venue for describing new applications of accelerators. At a time when not just old jobs but entire old industries are disappearing, accelerators and accelerator-driven light sources are burgeoning worldwide, offering new prospects not only for fundamental discovery science, but for medicine and biology, for energy and environment, for security, and for industry.

The award will be used to provide partial travel support for US students to attend the conference. The recipients of the travel support will be making presentations at the conference and will assist in conducting the conference. Attendance of 15 US students will be facilitated by the funds provided by this award. The conference will be an excellent opportunity for young scientists to interact with more experienced researchers and their colleagues in the broader international scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Particle Accelerator Conferences (IPAC) are an annual series of conferences that rotate between the Americas, Europe, and Asia to highlight the science and engineering of major accelerator facilities, provide scientists with fora for presenting results from research conducted using accelerators, and are a venue for describing new applications of accelerators, including those for medical uses. Old Dominion University was granted funding from NSF to support the participation of 7 US students in the conference to held in Copenhagen, Denmark in May 2017. In collaboration, the division of physics of beams of the American Physical Society supported 7 other students to attend IPAC'18.

Intellectual Merit:

The Eighth International Particle Accelerator Conference (IPAC’17) was the world’s leadingforum in 2017 for discussing the operation and construction of major accelerator facilities; scientific research results from accelerator laboratories; and applications of accelerators in manufacturing and health care. NSF funding was used to support travel for graduates students to present their research results in papers and posters, for many of these students it is the first such opportunities of their scientific careers. NSF’s support of IPAC17 programs was prominently acknowledged and highlighted one the Foundation’s important roles in accelerator-based research.

Broader Impacts:

IPAC17 organizers are aware of and fully-support the Foundation’s policy on Broader Impacts. At a time when not just old jobs but entire old industries are disappearing, accelerators and accelerator-driven light sources are burgeoning worldwide, offering new prospects not only for fundamental discovery science, but for medicine and biology, for energy and environment, for security, and for industry. International Particle Accelerator Conferences (IPAC) bring together world’s leading scientists in accelerator sciences and technologies, both from academe and industry, post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate researchers. IPACs are excellent venues for US graduate and undergraduate students to network with eminent scientists as well as their colleagues, providing potential collaborative and exchange opportunities. The students all presented and competed at least one poster presentation in the student poster session. Thirty-four individual talks were presented by the fourteen students supported by NSF and APS.
